instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW: What is SMC_BATLOW? SMC_BATLOW refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message:
came in liquid damaged, corrosion on clock area, SMC area, fan area and ISL area.

it didnt get a green light initially, so i've replaced the ISL, SMC. now i get green light.

i also have repaired the clock area, replaced <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> and some other stuff there.

replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, as there was some corrosion there.

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>'s (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL>) Pin 7 - trace was destroy, i replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and fixed the trace.

SPI ROM is missing PP3V3.



<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.59
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> S =  = 12.59
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.59
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> = 4.94
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.48V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>P5VSUS_SS</SIGNAL> = 4.8V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_DDR</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 0

​​​​​​​
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03
—————————————
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.317
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.317

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0"
Do you have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> high level?
Check voltages at <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>/22/40..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.33

<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>
--------
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.29
<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_SS</SIGNAL> = 3.29
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> = 0V


<CHIP>U7940</CHIP>
------------
pin1 = 0
pin3,4 = 0.6v
pin5 = 3.3v
pin6 = 3.3v


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
​​​​​​​

mmmmm damn,,

i've accidentally got it working..i get fan spin and chime.

if i press down with my finger on this area, the board will work:

there must be a bad trace or damaged component somewhere but the stuff there and back of the board looks good. [IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/upBi2n8.png[/IMG]
 

[media=youtube]BURtmoMr2gg[/media]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message:
actually i just need to touch it with my finger and will work. is it possible my skin's resistance causing it to work?



edit: i found it. if i put a micro brush with iPA on between <SIGNAL>DCIN_VSENSE_EN</SIGNAL>" and "<SIGNAL>DCINVSENS_EN_L</SIGNAL>" test points the board will start.

i've replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5490</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5492</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5494</RESISTOR>, and didn't solve.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> problem. Check <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR>. Possible SMC problem too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Dead
threads.message: thanks for your tips. it was <CHIP>U7940</CHIP>, problem solved.
